episode.content: *First broadcast on February 19, 2019. Between the 17th and 19th centuries, Christianity was banned in Japan. From the government's viewpoint, the Christian faith had put down roots worryingly quickly after being introduced by Jesuits. During the ban, believers faced unimaginable persecution. But some held onto their faith, and devised ways to worship in secret. In the first half of a two-part special, Japanology Plus introduces the story of the Hidden Christians. Our guests include Kiyomi Morooka, a Catholic priest in Nagasaki Prefecture.
episode.description: Hidden Christians Part 1: Japan's secret worshippers. Over the course of a two-part special, Peter Barakan visits key locations, and meets diverse experts with valuable insights.
episode.subtitle: Hidden Christians: Part 1
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on February 26, 2019. Between the 17th and 19th centuries, Christianity was banned in Japan. During the ban, believers faced unimaginable persecution. But some held onto their faith, and devised ways to worship in secret, often in remote locations such as Nagasaki's Goto Islands. In the second half of a two-part special, Japanology Plus features the Hidden Christians. Our guests include Yoshihiro Sakai, who continues to observe Hidden Christian practices.
episode.description: Hidden Christians (Part 2): Japan's secret worshippers. In the 2nd half of a two-part special, Peter Barakan visits key locations, and meets diverse experts with valuable insights.
episode.subtitle: Hidden Christians: Part 2
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on November 12, 2019. Plasterwork has been an indispensable feature of Japanese architecture for hundreds of years. You can see it on the walls of castles, storehouses, and everyday homes. Using a humble trowel, plasterers create lustrous surfaces and intricate reliefs. This time on Japanology Plus, our theme is plasterwork. Our guest is Takao Kobayashi, a 40-year veteran of the trade. He explains why he finds the work so captivating. And in Plus One, Matt Alt meets young trainees creating innovative twists on the plasterwork tradition.
episode.description: Plasterwork: Lustrous walls and intricate reliefs. Each time, Peter Barakan meets experts with fascinating cultural insights, while Matt Alt presents an entertaining take on the same theme.
episode.subtitle: Plasterwork
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on January 7, 2020. On New Year's Day, Japanese families gather to share a special meal called Osechi. It consists of multiple colorful dishes, often served in multi-tiered boxes. The custom has diversified in recent years, but it remains deeply rooted in Japanese society. This time, our theme is Osechi. Food history researcher Ayao Okumura discusses its little-known origins, and its continued importance. And in Plus One, Matt Alt looks at the chopsticks used to eat Osechi, and what they rest on.
episode.description: Osechi: New Year's Food. A traditional start to the year. Each time, Peter Barakan meets experts with fascinating cultural insights, while Matt Alt presents an entertaining take on the same theme.
episode.subtitle: Osechi: New Year's Food
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on March 10, 2020. In March 2011, a catastrophic earthquake and tsunami devastated communities on the east coast of Tohoku, northeast Japan. We visit the region 9 years on, to learn how people coped with the disaster and its aftermath. This time, we hear about survivors who say they've encountered the spirits of the dead. We also learn how bereaved parents use statues to stay in touch with children who have died. Our guests include Shigeru Kamei, who receives messages from his late wife in dreams.
episode.description: Tohoku Nine Years On: Living with Ghosts. Peter Barakan visits key locations in northeast Japan, and learns about people's outlook on life and death.
episode.subtitle: Tohoku Nine Years On: Living with Ghosts
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on March 17, 2020. In March 2011, a catastrophic earthquake and tsunami devastated communities on the east coast of Tohoku, northeast Japan. We visit the region 9 years on, to learn how people coped with the disaster and its aftermath. This time, we learn about folklore in Tono, where legends about supernatural beings serve as a medium for sharing the advice of ancestors. Our guests include Yuko Kikuchi, a professional storyteller. She speaks about the local tales, and explains why they're so important.
episode.description: Tohoku 9 Years On: Voices of the Deceased. Each time, Peter Barakan visits the key locations and meets experts with fascinating cultural insights.
episode.subtitle: Tohoku Nine Years On: Voices of the Deceased
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on April 21, 2020. Miso, a fermented soybean paste, is a bedrock of Japanese cuisine. For many Japanese, it offers a taste of home. It is made using koji mold, a fermentation starter that flourishes in Japan. This time on Japanology Plus, our theme is miso. Our guest, university professor Kanauchi Makoto, explains its health benefits, and demonstrates its many creative uses in Japanese cooking. And in Plus One, Matt Schley discovers the surprising new ways miso is being served in modern-day Japan.
episode.description: Miso. Japan's healthy and comforting taste of home. Each time, Peter Barakan meets experts with fascinating cultural insights, while in Plus One we seek out a different angle on the same theme.
episode.subtitle: Miso
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on August 4, 2020. Rakugo is a traditional form of storytelling that emerged in 17th century Japan. Using minimal props, a single performer creates amusing and sometimes moving scenes featuring multiple characters. Johan Nilsson Bjoerk, from Sweden, is one of Japan's very few foreign Rakugo professionals. In a Japanophiles interview, he tells Peter Barakan about the art form. He also talks about his 4 years as an apprentice to the veteran performer Sanyutei Koraku.
episode.description: Johan Nilsson Bjoerk: a Swedish rakugo storyteller. In a Japanophiles interview with Peter Barakan, Nilsson talks about rakugo--traditional Japanese storytelling--and about his time as an apprentice.
episode.subtitle: Japanophiles: Johan Nilsson Bjoerk
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on August 18, 2020. Over the centuries, Japan has suffered from repeated outbreaks of diseases like smallpox, measles and cholera. Where did the people of the past think these epidemics came from? And how did they cope? Our theme this time is Japan vs. Epidemics. Our main guest is Yamamoto Satomi, an art historian. She explains historical attitudes to disease by examining works of art, and the characters they feature. We also take a look at a contemporary social media trend.
episode.description: Japan vs. Epidemics. How did Japan cope in days gone by? Each time, Peter Barakan meets experts with fascinating cultural insights that present Japan in a different light.
episode.subtitle: Japan vs. Epidemics
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on September 1, 2020. Wasabi is a plant that grows natively in Japan's mountain valleys. It's used to make a condiment with a distinctive green color and an eye-watering impact. Most commonly served with sushi and soba, it is a pillar of Japanese cuisine. Our theme this time on Japanology Plus is wasabi. Our main guest is Mukasa Chieko, a food journalist. She talks about the plant's many surprising uses. We also meet Mita Shinichi, a farmer who explains the intricacies of wasabi cultivation.
episode.description: Wasabi. An eye-watering condiment with many surprising uses. Each time, Peter Barakan visits the key locations, and meets experts with fascinating cultural insights.
episode.subtitle: Wasabi
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on Sep. 29, 2020. South Korean film, TV drama and music have been popular in Japan for some time, but more recently there's been a growing appreciation for Korean literature. One of the major contributors to that trend is Kim Seungbok, from South Korea, who set up a publishing company and bookshop in Tokyo. In a Japanophiles interview, she tells Peter Barakan about her love of books, and about her efforts to introduce the literature of her home country to a Japanese audience.
episode.description: Kim Seungbok: A South Korean publisher and bookshop owner. In a Japanophiles interview, Kim tells Peter Barakan about her contribution to the booming popularity of Korean literature.
episode.subtitle: Japanophiles: Kim Seungbok
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on October 13, 2020. Kohfukuji, a World Heritage Site, is a prominent Buddhist temple in Nara, western Japan. One of its priests is Gyoei Saile, from Germany. In a Japanophiles interview, he tells Peter Barakan how his interest in Buddhism developed, and we learn about the extremely difficult exam he had to pass in order to become eligible to assume the abbacy of Kohfukuji. Saile also takes us through his daily routine, and offers thoughts on the role that Buddhism can play in contemporary Japan.
episode.description: Gyoei Saile: A German who became a Buddhist priest in Japan. In a Japanophiles interview, Saile tells Peter Barakan about how he came to be a priest at one of Japan's best-known temples.
episode.subtitle: Japanophiles: Gyoei Saile
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on November 24, 2020. The city of Tokyo is normally crowded with tourists at all times of the year, but the COVID-19 pandemic has transformed it. In a series called Tokyo Stories, Peter Barakan meets residents not originally from Japan, to hear how their lives have been affected. This time he speaks with Mateusz Urbanowicz, from Poland. He paints scenes from the city, such as the colorful storefronts of independent shops, and rainy, neon-lit nightscapes. He explains his view of Tokyo's urban development.
episode.description: Mateusz Urbanowicz: Portraying scenes from the city. In a Tokyo Stories interview, Urbanowicz shows Peter Barakan how he researches his work, and how he sees Tokyo's urban development.
episode.subtitle: Tokyo Stories #2: Mateusz Urbanowicz
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on November 17, 2020. The city of Tokyo is normally crowded with tourists, but the COVID-19 pandemic has transformed the city's sightseeing spots. In a series called Tokyo Stories, Peter Barakan meets Tokyo residents who are not originally from Japan, to hear how their lives have been affected. This time he meets Josh Grisdale, who was born in Canada. Due to cerebral palsy, Grisdale has only limited movement in his arms and legs. He talks about his daily life, and the theme of accessibility in the realm of tourism.
episode.description: Josh Grisdale: Promoting accessible tourism. In a Tokyo Stories interview, Grisdale speaks with Peter Barakan about the theme of accessibility in the realm of tourism.
episode.subtitle: Tokyo Stories #1: Josh Grisdale
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on December 1, 2020. The Ainu people are indigenous to Japan, and the Ainu community is now concentrated in Hokkaido Prefecture, the northernmost main island. The Ainu have long maintained a distinct culture and language, but very few speakers of the language remain. In a Japanophiles interview, Peter Barakan meets Anna Bugaeva, a Russian linguist who has spent 2 decades recording and analyzing the Ainu language. She shares some of the insights she has acquired through her long association with Ainu culture.
episode.description: Anna Bugaeva: A Russian linguist studying the Ainu language. In a Japanophiles interview, Bugaeva tells Peter Barakan about the language of the Ainu, an indigenous people now concentrated in Hokkaido.
episode.subtitle: Japanophiles: Anna Bugaeva
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on December 22, 2020. Japan is home to thousands of different mushroom species. Some can be found lining the supermarket shelves, but others serve as natural tourist attractions, and even a poisonous species may be used to make dye. This time on Japanology Plus, our theme is mushrooms. Our main guest is Eguchi Fumio. He talks about his research into the health benefits of mushrooms, and their potential use in new medicines. And in Plus One, we discover some of Japan's more unusual species.
episode.description: Mushrooms. The incredible diversity of Japan's fungi. Each time, Peter Barakan visits the key locations, and meets experts with fascinating cultural insights.
episode.subtitle: Mushrooms
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on December 29, 2020. Kamishibai, or paper theater, is a form of storytelling that uses large picture cards. It was wildly popular throughout Japan in the 1930's. Today, it's still enjoyed in kindergartens and libraries. This time, our theme is Kamishibai. Our main guest, Sakai Kyoko, talks about how Kamishibai titles are created, and how they should be performed. And in Plus One, we meet American poet Arthur Binard, whose own Kamishibai communicates the horror of the atomic bomb.
episode.description: Kamishibai: Paper Theater. Storytelling using picture cards. Each time, Peter Barakan visits the key locations, and meets experts with fascinating cultural insights.
episode.subtitle: Kamishibai: Paper Theater
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on January 12, 2021. This time, our theme is moss. In some countries, it is regarded almost as a weed, but in Japan, it's cherished. Moss can be found in the gardens of temples and shrines, in forests and mountains and even in large cities. Our main guest is Oishi Yoshitaka, an associate professor at Fukui Prefectural University. He introduces us to different species of moss, and explains the role it plays in both the natural world, and in Japanese gardening. And in Plus One, Kanoa makes a beautiful moss terrarium.
episode.description: Moss. A cherished feature of gardens and natural scenery. Each time, Peter Barakan visits the key locations, and meets experts with fascinating cultural insights.
episode.subtitle: Moss
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on January 19, 2021. Japan's libraries are cornerstones of their communities. Besides loaning out books, they promote local culture, support young people and offer a place to relax. This time, our theme is libraries. Our main guest, Professor Tamura Shigeru of the University of Nagano, talks about how they have evolved in recent years, in response to demographic and legal changes. And in Plus One, we take a look at some unusual regional libraries.
episode.description: Libraries. Cornerstones of Japanese communities. Each time, Peter Barakan visits the key locations, and meets experts with fascinating cultural insights.
episode.subtitle: Libraries
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on January 26, 2021. The kimono, Japan's national garment, is generally seen as traditional clothing -- something to wear on special occasions. But these days, modern and stylish kimono are making an impact in the fashion world. In a Japanophiles interview, Peter Barakan meets Sheila Cliffe, from the UK, who fell in love with kimono during a trip to Japan, and went on to become an authority on the subject. She talks about her life journey, and presents some contemporary styles.
episode.description: Sheila Cliffe: A kimono expert and enthusiast from the UK. In a Japanophiles interview, Cliffe tells Peter Barakan about her career and contemporary trends in kimono fashion.
episode.subtitle: Japanophiles: Sheila Cliffe
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on February 2, 2021. Ukiyo-e is a Japanese artform that emerged in the 17th century. Using woodblock prints, people and landscapes are brought to life with bold compositions and vivid colors. The images influenced European artists such as van Gogh, and they remain part of the visual landscape in modern Japan. Our main guest, art historian Fujisawa Murasaki, introduces several examples of ukiyo-e, and talks about its legacy. And in Plus One, Matt Alt searches Tokyo for locations featured in famous ukiyo-e pictures.
episode.description: Ukiyo-e. Traditional Japanese woodblock prints. Each time, Peter Barakan visits the key locations, and meets experts with fascinating cultural insights.
episode.subtitle: Ukiyo-e
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on March 16, 2021. On March 11, 2011, a magnitude 9 earthquake off the coast of northeast Japan caused a devastating tsunami that left around 18,000 people dead or unaccounted for. Ishinomaki, in Miyagi Prefecture, was one of the worst-affected areas. In a Japanophiles interview, Peter Barakan meets a long-term resident of the city: Richard Halberstadt, from the UK. Halberstadt talks about the disaster and its aftermath, and explains why he decided to stay and help Ishinomaki recover.
episode.description: Richard Halberstadt: Ten years on from the 2011 disaster. In a Japanophiles interview, Halberstadt tells Peter Barakan about his life in Ishinomaki, a city devastated by the March 2011 tsunami.
episode.subtitle: Japanophiles: Richard Halberstadt
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on April 8, 2021. Japanese use a wide range of cleaning implements, from old-fashioned brooms to modern carpet rollers. There's always a dedicated tool for the job. Sometimes, those tools have a deeper meaning. Our main guest, museum researcher Watanabe Yumiko, explains their special significance, and talks about the evolution of Japanese cleaning tools over time. We also meet broom-maker Kanbara Ryosuke, who shows us how traditional handmade brooms are put together.
episode.description: Cleaning Tools. Specialized devices and deeper meanings. Each time, Peter Barakan visits the key locations, and meets experts with fascinating cultural insights.
episode.subtitle: Cleaning Tools
episode.title: Japanology Plus

episode.content: *First broadcast on April 22, 2021. Lacquerware is made by coating objects with the sap of the lacquer tree. It's a traditional craft that dates back thousands of years. Lacquer offers incredible durability, as well as a distinctive luster that develops over time. Our main guest, Professor Hidaka Kaori, explains how production techniques are evolving to meet the needs of the modern world. We also see David Morrison Pike, an American potter, demonstrating Kintsugi, a technique that uses lacquer to repair broken ceramics.
episode.description: Lacquerware. Durable objects with a distinctive luster. Each time, Peter Barakan visits key locations and meets experts with fascinating cultural insights.
episode.subtitle: Lacquerware
episode.title: Japanology Plus
